docs.lead_paragraph: Certified registered nurse anesthetists are nurses who complete three years of advanced training in anesthesia that legally allows them to give anesthesia without a doctor's supervision in 50 states. But Medicare rules, which tend to set standards for all patients, require physician supervision in hospitals. In November, the Bush administration rejected a Clinton administration proposal to let nurse anesthetists work unsupervised in hospitals. Gale Scott spoke to members of opposing professional groups about the issue. Following are edited excerpts of those interviews. YES. Certified registered nurse anesthetists offer safe quality care to their patients. One indicator of that is that our malpractice insurance premiums have decreased 50 percent over the last decade. According to the National Practitioners' Data Bank, nurse-anesthetists made one-seventh the malpractice payments that doctors made in 1990 to 1997.
